docs.lead_paragraph: An interactive media systems company, OpenTV, has filed a claim to broaden one of its patents to include ''one-click'' shopping and set-top storage of personal data, which the company says may supersede the patent that Amazon.com is trying to assert against Barnesandnoble.com. OpenTV asked the federal Patent and Trademark Office to expand the scope of its original patent to include the TV commerce technology. OpenTV said because of the early filing date of its original patent, and the publication of the European equivalent patent application, ''Amazon could be precluded from using its patents against'' anyone else using the technology. Amazon.com has filed suit against Barnesandnoble.com, saying that its one-click ordering system infringed on a patent it was awarded in September. ''One-click'' systems store users' billing and shipping information so they do not have to be re-entered on each visit.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE anthropologist Napoleon A. Chagnon has spent decades studying patterns of conflict and revenge among Yanomami Indians, deep within the Amazon Basin. He needn't have traveled so far to pursue his research. After all, anthropologists themselves are one of the most bellicose tribes on earth. The discipline's latest outbreak of infighting -- over accusations of ''ethnographic cleansing'' made against Mr. Chagnon in an upcoming book, ''Darkness in El Dorado'' -- may be its nastiest battle yet. Disputes within anthropology have a way of becoming blood feuds. Virtually all of the field's leading figures have been struck by poison arrows. Margaret Mead? Dupe! Franz Boas? Spy! Colin Turnbull? Hoaxer! Marshall Sahlins? Imperialist! Indeed, the excessive ferocity of anthropological warfare has fractured the discipline and tarnished its public image. It's become the academic equivalent of ''The Jerry Springer Show.''

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; Anthropology Enters the Age of Cannibalism

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is good reason why Internet auctions have sapped millions of working hours from businesses and chained otherwise attentive parents to their PC's on evenings and weekends. Not only can auctions yield bargains, but there are few other places where you can compete against a potential pool of hundreds of millions of people and emerge as the winner. Given the fact that, like auctions, online travel has been a runaway favorite among Web surfers, it seemed only a matter of time before the two ideas were melded. Now some of the earliest travel-related auction sites are starting to gain momentum among consumers, with one site, BidForVacations .com, securing a spot among the 10 most visited travel sites in August, according to the Internet research company PCData, and others attracting increasing numbers of visitors as well.

docs.lead_paragraph: MIDTOWN Your Space or Mine: Sympathy for the Pedestrian Public plazas and atriums have become fixtures in New York, spurred by zoning changes in 1961 that offered pedestrians breathing room as a tradeoff for taller towers. But questions have been raised as to their success. Most recently a study supported by the Municipal Art Society found that nearly half of the city's 503 public plazas and atriums did not comply with city rules. The legacy of and impact of these privately owned public spaces is being examined in the Municipal Art Society's exhibition ''The World's Most Expensive Public Space.'' It features photographs, models, drawings and maps of 300 of these spaces. In addition, a series of public programs on the topic will include walking tours, a panel discussion and symposium, and a film screening.

docs.lead_paragraph: The cart advanced slowly up the avenue, a small wooden statue of the Virgin Mary mounted atop it and hundreds of thousands of people straining at least to touch the rope that created a protected space around the image. Those lucky enough to grasp the thick cord held on tightly, their sweaty faces contorted by fatigue and fervor, as the procession meandered for eight hours to a basilica just three miles away. All week long the pilgrims have been streaming into this port city on foot and by boat, bus and plane, coming from as far as 1,000 miles away to take part in a ritual that has been a part of life in the Amazon for more than 200 years. Today, with the second Sunday of October having finally arrived, the Cirio de Nazare, the biggest religious festival in the country with the largest Roman Catholic population in the world, was once again celebrated here.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the men and women stationed at this Canadian military base prepare to kick off four months of polar night with a ''sunset party'' on Oct. 14, the threat of global warming seems far from the northernmost human settlement in the world. Until the sun peeks over the horizon again on March 1, workers going outside will clip themselves to orange rope ''lifelines'' to avoid getting lost in the frigid, 24-hour night. Artificially built like a lunar colony, this combined weather station and radio listening post stands on a barren, treeless bluff halfway between Canada's last Inuit community and the North Pole, 507 miles north of here. Alert, in the territory of Nunavut, is as far from Toronto, 2,700 miles, as New York City is from the Amazon.

docs.lead_paragraph: Fifteen years ago, a handful of fast-growing national bookstore chains started a price war on discounting books that became one of the momentous trends in the book business. Widespread markdowns on best sellers, tens of thousands of other hardcover titles and even paperbacks delighted consumers and increased book sales. The low prices lured customers to the national chains from independent stores and pumped up best sellers' sales by making them much cheaper than other titles. And when Amazon.com joined the game five years ago, its online book store upped the ante on competitive discounts.

headline.main: Quietly, Booksellers Are Putting an End To the Discount Era

docs.lead_paragraph: THE average Web surfer opens the Netscape or Internet Explorer browser, punches in a Web address, comes to a Web page, then clicks from page to page. When lost, the person tries to maneuver through an array of bookmarks or, more often than not, resorts to the Back button. In 1994, that page-turning process seemed revolutionary. Today, it not only sounds run-of-the-mill but is also considered by many new Internet companies to be, well, ridiculous. Why should a person who wants a few headlines have to open a full page of information? Why should anyone have to click on link after link to get to the right information? And how many people really go back to all those Web sites they bookmark?

docs.lead_paragraph: The largest guerrilla group in Colombia has denied reports that it kidnapped 10 foreign oil workers on Thursday in the Amazon region of Ecuador, further clouding the fate of the captives, who were apparently flown by a hijacked helicopter into Colombia. But Clinton administration officials said they had every indication that the group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, was responsible. They said Ecuadorean Army units had intercepted a radio message from the helicopter that said a gunman on board had identified the group as FARC members. The gunman reportedly said the action was intended as a protest against a stepped-up effort by Colombia and the United States against coca plantings in southern Colombia, American officials said.

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show. Museums ''AMAZONS OF THE AVANT-GARDE,'' Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 7). A concise exercise, monographically arranged, this show focuses on six Russian women who painted around the time of the revolution. Several continued to work much later and do more than paint, but this is a tendentious affair, plausibly so. If only a couple of the women, Natalia Goncharova and Liubov Popova, were truly great painters, the exhibition still isn't a case of special pleading. The Russian avant-garde wouldn't have been what it was without them collectively. The story as it unfolds here seems, if anything, more remarkable, not less, for having as little to do with sex as it does and almost everything to do with painting. Many of the works have a surprising fortitude. Revolution. A brave new art world. The dream persists even though the form it takes keeps changing. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8 for students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).

docs.lead_paragraph: In the coming presidential election, a third-party candidate best represents our beliefs, but we fear that a vote for him will help elect the worse of the two major-party candidates. However, to vote out of fear for the less bad major-party candidate works against desired long-term change. So, which is better: to vote for good or against evil? -- K. Cohen and M. Hoffmann, Portland, Ore. It is as honorable to oppose the wicked as to champion the good, and it is a traditional part of American politics. In 1946, Republican Congressional candidates ran under the slogan ''Had Enough? Vote Republican.'' Two years later, the C.I.O. chief Philip Murray, campaigning for Truman, declared, ''We don't want our government under the control of bankers and corporate interests.'' Even that most-invoked of ethical guides, the Ten Commandments, presents most of its rules in negative terms, or as votes against -- thou shalt not (although it takes no explicit position on the Truman-Dewey race).

docs.lead_paragraph: Counting the 170 million or so inhabitants of a country that is larger than the 48 contiguous United States is not easy. But taking the census in the Amazon jungle, some of the most inhospitable terrain on earth, is even harder, as France Maria de Souza discovered when she set off one morning to interview 22 families living on an isolated island near here. Under a broiling tropical sun, Ms. de Souza, a 26-year-old schoolteacher, boarded a small uncovered motorboat, slipped on a life jacket -- nervously, since she does not know how to swim -- and counted her supply of census forms as the craft moved out into the broad Solimoes River. She knew she was working against the clock: the rainy season in this part of the Amazon begins in mid-November, and some communities may soon be inaccessible.

docs.lead_paragraph: Until recently, this town on the corner of the frontiers of Brazil, Peru and Colombia was one of the most sleepy, remote and overlooked parts of the Amazon. But that was before the fighting upriver by army troops, guerrillas and paramilitary forces on Colombia's side of the 1,021-mile border started to intensify. Suddenly, the Brazilian government is stepping up river patrols and air surveillance and destroying clandestine airstrips, driven by a concern that the $1.3 billion the United States has promised Colombia to bolster its army may further fuel the long war against drug traffickers and their guerrilla allies and send it spilling into Brazil.

docs.lead_paragraph: BUSINESS-MINDED archaeologists who pick through the rubble of the e-tailing fiasco will have little trouble piecing together what went wrong. With every new rollout of a Web store in 1998 and 1999 came declarations that the shop in question would revolutionize the buying experience by making it so much easier than shopping the traditional way. The truth, of course, is that it was too seldom truly easy. Poorly designed sites could turn the experience into one of hair-tugging frustration that was just as slow as a trip to the local store. Factor in problems with privacy, security, customer service and shipping, and it is little wonder why the revolution has been slow to arrive.

docs.lead_paragraph: The online retailer Amazon.com introduced a Japanese-language Web site offering more than 1.7 million Japanese and English titles. The new site (Amazon.co.jp) will also include book reviews, recommendation lists and interviews with authors and translators. ''We can now make our customer-centric shopping experience -- great service, selection and convenience -- available to everyone looking for popular or hard-to-find Japanese-language books,'' said Jeff Bezos, above, the company's chief executive. Japan is Amazon's fourth foreign operation, after Germany, Britain and France, and the first one in Asia. Despite Mr. Bezos's enthusiasm, many analysts and industry observers are cool on Amazon's move in Japan. The market has begun to look crowded, with dozens of players including Kinokuniya, a big book retailer; E-Shopping Books, backed by Softbank; and Bertelsmann's BOL.com. Miki Tanikawa

docs.lead_paragraph: It's now official: We have learned far more about George W. Bush and Al Gore than they know about themselves. The press has at last plumbed the shallows of both men, and even the ''November surprise,'' a Fox reporter's revelation of Mr. Bush's police blotter during his blotto years, is not up to Rupert Murdoch's top scandal standards. There may be little choice now but to move on to those nostalgic staples of photo-finish horse races: What if it's a tie? What if the popular-vote victor loses the Electoral College? Most entertaining of all is this year's last-minute human-interest sideshow, ''Dead Man Running'': If Missouri elects a corpse to the Senate, can it still purport to be the ''Show Me'' state? Whatever happens on Tuesday, the presidential race remains a contest over character. It's not the immutable personalities of the two contenders that are in play, though, but that of the country. Democrats are having fits that Mr. Bush, whom they see as a nincompoop, has a serious shot at winning. But the Texas governor's unexpected prowess cannot be attributed merely to the staggering ineptitude of Mr. Gore's candidacy. Mr. Bush, who applies his selective memory equally to his personal history and the country's, may have actually caught the cultural wave of the moment. Love it or leave it, we just may be living in George W.'s America.

headline.main: Journal; George W.'s America

docs.lead_paragraph: O BRAVE new ''CyberWorld''! In the latest attraction from Imax, golden heads fly by in formation on golden wings through clouds of rods and cones that disperse like shimmering liquid. The patriarch of ''The Simpsons'' slips into the universe of ''that wheelchair guy,'' and falls down a black hole. Wondrous moments, and who cares about continuity? This is 3-D, for heaven's sake. Let's not get all linear. Sailing in the wake of Disney's ''Fantasia/2000,'' which scaled up traditional, two-dimensional animation to the format of the eight-story screen, ''CyberWorld'' masquerades as the 3-D ''Fantasia'': a state-of-the-art sound-and-light show that pops into the third dimension. But whereas both the original ''Fantasia'' and the recent sequel were episodic feature films built from scratch, ''CyberWorld'' is in effect a composite trailer for the uncharted future of a medium-in-progress.

docs.lead_paragraph: RUSSIANS of a certain age are apt to regard the state of Iowa with slightly mordant nostalgia. Nikita S. Khrushchev passed through during his 1959 official visit to America. He took home some Iowa corn, ordered his collective farmers to grow it, produced a historic crop failure and . . . well, you know the rest. But that was not the reason 14 Russian composers and musicologists gathered recently for a long weekend at the University of Iowa here. Khrushchev's corn mania was nurtured at Iowa State, which has a famous agricultural college. The Iowa City institution (best known, perhaps, for its Writers' Workshop) has long been distinguished in contemporary-music circles. In 1966, with Rockefeller Foundation money, it set up a Center for New Music, one of the earliest campus performance outlets of its kind.

docs.lead_paragraph: While other archaeologists spend their careers looking for ''lost'' cities, Dr. Clark L. Erickson of the University of Pennsylvania Museum keeps a practiced eye out for ''lost'' landscapes. His explorations in the Amazon basin of Bolivia have uncovered distinct traces of major earth-moving modifications to the landscape made by pre-European cultures. These ancient landscape engineers transformed unpromising savannas and wetlands into prime agricultural land by draining here and piling dirt there, creating settlement mounds and raised fields for crops, long causeways and canals.

docs.lead_paragraph: The writer Susan Sontag won the National Book Award for Fiction last night for ''In America,'' a postmodern novel about a 19th-century Polish actress' attempt to establish a utopian community in California. The book, published this year by Farrar, Straus & Giroux, was partly inspired by the true story of the Polish actress Helena Modjeska, who came to America in the last century. The awards were announced at the Marriott Marquis in Manhattan, with the comedian Steve Martin, who has just published his first novel, ''Shopgirl'' (Hyperion), as host. ''It's slowly dawning on me that I will not be receiving an award tonight,'' he said.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN I was growing up, my family greeted the arrival of the holiday season with a sacred tradition: we shopped. We also cared deeply for the ritual of wrapping, which generally led to bitter accusations that someone was hoarding the expensive silver foil paper and counter-charges of excessive cellophane tape usage. The buildup culminated in a frenzied three-minute celebration, as 40 assembled relatives simultaneously ripped open 400 gifts, filling the shared airspace with so much discarded packaging that one year my mother lost sight of the baby. Luckily, my father rushed in with a Online Shopper squad of cleanup specialists, consisting of my brothers armed with jumbo Hefty bags. They shouted coordinates -- ''There's an unsecured gift card at four o'clock'' -- into their new walkie-talkies and removed stray ribbons from the necks of the weak or elderly.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a back room in a small apartment along a quiet street, Capt. Clive Kelly lies in repose, a force of nature aground on a rumpled futon. In August, Kelly's seagoing adventures and 30-year environmental crusade came to an abrupt halt when his 55-foot trimaran was shipwrecked on a reef off this lush Caribbean island. Now, it appears Kelly might be becalmed for quite some time. Kelly has been confined to bed because of multiple injuries -- some sustained during the battle to keep his boat, Survival, afloat; others from a fall off the deck after it was hauled ashore. For diversions, Kelly has his scrapbooks and a television. Flashing across the screen, a video of an award-winning documentary from 1978 features Kelly as the protege of an Amazon Indian chief named Raoni.

docs.lead_paragraph: And now the aging labor movement takes on one of the superstars of the new economy, Amazon.com. The Communications Workers of America, the United Food and Commercial Workers, and the Prewitt Fund, an independent organizing group, are seeking to unionize 400 of Amazon's customer-service workers and 5,000 of its warehouse workers. With the workers' vaunted stock options nosediving in value, many Amazon workers have begun grumbling about their modest wages, causing them to look more kindly toward unions. If labor succeeds in organizing Amazon's workers -- some labor experts say it is a long shot -- it would be labor's biggest foothold in high-technology America. Steven Greenhouse

docs.lead_paragraph: AT&T Shares Climb Slightly On Equipment-Buying Halt AT&T, whose stock is down 62 percent so far this year, had a reprieve after it halted purchases of equipment that enabled its cable systems to carry local telephone service. That move sent shares of equipment suppliers sharply lower, while shares of AT&T rose 38 cents, to $19.13. AT&T Broadband, its cable division, said the move was the result of streamlining its inventory-tracking procedures to cut equipment stockpiles. It expects to resume buying early next year. AT&T's decision comes at a time when the market for communications equipment appears to be cooling. [Page C3.]

docs.lead_paragraph: No place in Colombia is farther from Bogota, and thus further from the thoughts of bureaucrats in the capital, than this sweltering Amazon jungle town. Brazil is just down the street, the border marked only by a miniature obelisk in front of a liquor store, and Peru is a mere five-minute motorboat ride across the Amazon. Of course, the residents of neighboring Tabatinga, Brazil, and Santa Rosa, Peru, have also been known to complain about being ignored by their national governments. Yet life in this remote region known as the Three Frontiers has traditionally offered certain advantages, especially when compared with the political turmoil that has engulfed the rest of Colombia and Peru.

headline.main: Leticia Journal; Dancing Across an Imaginary Line in the Jungle

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR three weeks, the question has been nagging Americans: how can the most technologically advanced nation on earth have such antiquated, unreliable, confusing voting technology? How can the outcome of the presidential race dangle with the chads left on 1975-style punch cards? Tapping this frustration, two of the Senate's most publicity-savvy members, Arlen Specter, the Pennsylvania Republican, and Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat, called for federal studies of voting procedures. In his announcement, Mr. Schumer labeled the current system ''antediluvian.''

docs.lead_paragraph: For Internet companies facing the prospect of bankruptcy, the list of assets they can sell to pay off creditors is similar to the assets most companies try to sell when they close up shop: inventory, equipment, real estate, trademarks -- and, in many cases, troves of customer information. But customer data like names and addresses, which are bought and sold routinely in the offline world, have become controversial in the online context, as beleaguered Internet companies and their bankruptcy lawyers contemplate which assets they can put on the auction block. The sticking point is the companies' own privacy policies -- the very safeguards many Internet companies put in place to reassure customers that their personal information would never be shared with a third party.

docs.lead_paragraph: If you are looking at the pictures, the best art books are likely to be the newest. The quality of color reproduction just keeps getting better. But if you're also reading the words, all bets are off. The best art criticism, in every age, tells us something about the art under consideration and something about the critic. Rilke on Rodin, Baudelaire on Delacroix, Meyer Schapiro on Cezanne -- once you have read these writers, the works of art are never quite the same again. And yet, art keeps asking something new from us, what Robert Frost called ''counterlove, original response.'' Word and picture, image and text -- the terms kept shifting in my mind, like yin wrestling with yang, as I meandered among the harvest of this year's art books. CHARDIN. By Pierre Rosenberg et al. (Yale University/Metropolitan Museum, $65.) CHARDIN. By Pierre Rosenberg and Renaud Temperini. (Prestel, $65.) Even to his contemporaries there seemed something magical about Chardin's still lifes. ''O Chardin!'' the 18th-century critic and philosopher Diderot wrote, ''it is not white, red or black that you grind onto your palette, but the very substance of things.'' That air of disbelief and wonder runs through these two books on Chardin, the one a catalog of an exhibition seen last year and this in Paris, Dsseldorf, London and at the Metropolitan Musem of Art, the other a painstaking life-and-works survey of Chardin's career. Pierre Rosenberg, president and director of the Louvre in Paris, is the principal author of both; curators and Chardin scholars contributed essays to the catalog, and the art historian Renaud Temperini is the co-author of the monograph.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN an editor called a few years ago to ask if I'd write a children's book, I thought it would be an easy way to become a best-selling author. A picture book, after all, is only 32 pages. The publisher, Callaway, known for discovering David Kirk, creator of the hit ''Miss Spider'' series, already had a talented illustrator named Dasha Ziborova, who had a thing for cats, so all I had to do was come up with a story that jived with her sensibility. I rallied with ''Crispin the Terrible,'' the story of an arch yet easily intimidated cat with family issues, who feels so unappreciated that he fantasizes about striking out on his own. When my editor took an early draft of my story to the Frankfurt Book Fair to try to sell foreign publishing rights, one German publisher hissed, ''Why should anyone care about this cat?'' Two years later, with the book finally out (after endless revisions that drove me to the edge of despair), it's hard not to wonder the same thing.

docs.lead_paragraph: The search for the source of the Nile, the world's longest river, inspired heroic explorations into the African interior by the British in the 19th century. They eventually learned that at its most distant reaches, the Nile flows out of Lake Victoria, in what is now Tanzania. The Amazon is almost as long as the Nile and the volume of water it carries to the sea is far greater. Yet the Amazon's headwaters have been less of an alluring mystery. As long ago as the 17th century, a Jesuit missionary, Cristoval de Acuna, hypothesized that the river sprang from the heights of the Andes in Peru, and all subsequent explorations bore him out.

docs.lead_paragraph: Wonder Woman, the first popular female comic-book character, was considered so representative of feminism that she appeared on the cover of the first issue of Ms. magazine, but she was really more of a twisted sister. According to Les Daniels's WONDER WOMAN: The Life and Times of the Amazon Princess (Chronicle, $29.95), she was created in 1941-42 by a Harvard-trained psychologist named William Moulton Marston as, in his words, ''psychological propaganda for the new type of woman who should, I believe, rule the world.'' The early comics were rife with intimations of lesbianism, bondage and discipline. The all-female Paradise Island bore more than a passing resemblance to Lesbos, and the superheroine's favorite epithet was ''Suffering Sappho!'' She managed to get herself tied up or bound by exotic methods in virtually every installment. In one choice panel, Wonder Woman hogties an Atlantean giantess while exclaiming, ''On Paradise Island where we play many binding games this is considered the safest method of tying a girl's arms!'' ''Women enjoy submission,'' insisted Marston, who lived in a menage trois. Ninety percent of Wonder Woman's fans may have been male (the Nancy Sinatra boots, spangly shorts and Versace bustier didn't hurt). The text by Daniels, who has also given the same super-treatment to Superman and Batman, is unfortunately not as colorful as its subject matter, but there are some wonderful arcana: a photograph of a very young Debra Winger as Wonder Girl standing next to the Junoesque Lynda Carter from the television series, and one of a Wonder-Woman-shaped scissors. We won't touch the Freudian implications of that one. Eric P. Nash

docs.lead_paragraph: It's not unusual to find a school's fund-raising cookbook for sale. But it is far from typical to find one for sale at Amazon.com or Barnes & Noble. The Joseph Kushner Hebrew Academy-Yeshiva High School, a modern Orthodox school in Livingston, put out the ''The Kosher Palette'' last March. Now in its third printing, it has sold 15,000 copies. Sandra Blank and Susie Fishbein solicited recipes from other school parents, and sold the resulting book in local stores and through the school. But, Ms. Fishbein said, word spread and within weeks Amazon.com called her, saying it had received many inquiries about the book. She said the book filled a need for a kosher cookbook for everyday use. The book, $26.95, can be still be purchased directly from the school at (973) 597-1115, extension 197, but sales from any source all bring money into the school. One reader-reviewer on Amazon said, ''This is a book to drool over.''

docs.lead_paragraph: LARRY COHEN, executive vice president of the Communications Workers of America, is one of the labor movement's chief strategists in trying to unionize high-technology workers. He wants to develop models for new-economy unionism. His union is seeking to organize hundreds of customer service workers at Amazon.com. It is involved in the first unionization vote at a dot-com company, Etown.com, a Web site that sells electronics. Most customer service workers there asked for the election, scheduled for next month, saying they wanted to join the communications workers.

docs.lead_paragraph: For Internet merchants, this holiday season is bringing little joy, and not much comfort, either. Online retail sales are up again, with estimates of the increase over last year varying from 50 to 100 percent. Visa says 3.5 percent of the spending on its credit cards over the holiday season has been done online, double the share last year, and almost five times that of 1998.

headline.main: Last Noel for Some Dot-Coms; Traditional Chains Making Inroads in the Online Market

docs.abstract: Online retail sales are estimated to rise of between 50 percent and 100 percent over last year, but fall short of many predictions; and a great percentage of Internet merchants' sales have been gleaned by online affiliates of conventional stores, to the dismay of Web-only merchants, many of whom will likely not survive; photo; list (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For those wondering why they won't be giving or getting the season's hottest gift, the Sony PlayStation 2, we asked a few proud owners to explain how they managed to get their hands on a game that has been scarce since its debut on Oct. 26, when planned shipments of one million units were cut to 500,000 because of Sony's earlier troubles getting the right parts. GAMER: Justin Hall, 26, Oakland, Calif. WHEN HE WON: Oct. 26 WINNING STRATEGY: Amazon.com. ''First I went to Target at 6:10 a.m., and there were like 70 people ahead of me. When everybody found out they only had 50, people started calling all over the place on their cell phones, and the rumors were buzzing: 'They have some at Montgomery Ward.' 'A guy 15 people back says Best Buy's the place to go.' I stopped by Montgomery Ward on the way to work. Of course they didn't have any. At work I heard Amazon was selling some at noon and set my calendar to remind me. I hit reload over and over again and I got one. It was like winning the golden ticket from 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.' I'm giving it to my 10- and 7-year-old nephews for Christmas. They'd better think I'm the coolest uncle in the world.''

docs.lead_paragraph: WE all have our Christmas rituals. Chestnuts roasting on an open fire. Getting sloppy drunk on spiked supermarket eggnog and screaming yourself to sleep. Did I say that out loud? No, my real Christmas ritual is ''A Christmas Carol,'' the 1951 version starring Alastair Sim. It wouldn't be Christmas Eve without it. As a kid, I stayed up late with my mother, sometimes my grandmother, not minding that it was black-and-white because so was our television. Now, I watch with other hard-core devotees who think this is not just one of the best Christmas movies but one of the best movies ever made.

docs.lead_paragraph: Brazil's biggest telephone company, Telemar, has bought the Internet access arm of the online media company iG, iG said today on its Web site. The value of the acquisition will not be disclosed until the start of 2001, though the Brazilian news media have speculated that Telemar might pay about 50 million reais, or $26 million, for the iG unit. Officials at Telemar and iG were not immediately available for comment.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I did most of my Christmas shopping this year on the Internet, and most of that was with Amazon. Of all the orders I placed (including three at Amazon), everything arrived early except an order I placed at Amazon on Dec. 13 (Amazon warned me that it might not arrive by Christmas, and I was prepared to take my chances, but it showed up on Christmas Eve).

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Hard to Tell When a Virtual Shelf Is Bare,'' Online Shopper, Dec. 21: My daughter lives in Kentucky, I live in Hawaii and I thought that if I ordered her present early from the best and biggest online merchant, Amazon.com, I'd be O.K. I am angry because I ordered the Christmas present on Dec. 10, and the item was available and supposed to be shipped in 24 hours. After placing the order I waited to see my item shipped. By Dec. 17, I noticed that it had not been shipped, and I knew that it would never arrive in time.

docs.lead_paragraph: A plastic cat that whistles incessantly has beaten out the radio-controlled snake, the sock puppet from a bankrupt dot-com and a talking dump truck to become the surprise toy hit of the holiday season. Shoppers snatched Meow-Chi, a robotic cat, off store shelves in the final weeks before Christmas, and toy retailers characterized it yesterday as the sleeper of the season.
